characters: WE SEE A LIST OF LETTERS
A COMPUTER VERSION OF COLUMBUS AVENUE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early morning in New York. A couple of runners pass on th way to Riverside Drive Park. We go through the brownstone window into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHLEEN KELLY is asleep.  Kathleen, 30, is as pretty and fresh as a spring day.  Her bedroom's cozy, has a queen-s bed and a desk with a computer on it.  Bookshelves line e inch of wall space and overflow with books.  Framed on th wall: the cover of the children's classic, Madeleine. As Kathleen wakes up, her boyfriend FRANK NAVASKY walks i the room.  He wears blue jeans and a workshirt.  He's car the New York Times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he reads)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to this -- the entire work  force of the state of Virginia had  to have solitaire removed from their  computers -- Kathleen gets out of bed and goes to brush her teeth in t bathroom, and we stay with Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- because they hadn't done any work  in six weeks. Kathleen comes out of the bathroom in her robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what this is, you know what  we're seeing here?  We're seeing the  end of Western civilization as we  know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is so sad. She tosses him his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points at her computer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think that machine is your friend,  but it's not. (checks his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Frank walks to the apartment door.  We see a charming  room with a couch, fireplace, books, and a dining table w a typewriter with a cover on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sushi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.  Bye.
Frank goes out the door.  It closes. Kathleen tiptoes into the hall and looks through the fish eye peephole watching as he goes down the stairs, disappe from sight.  She walks into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And looks out the front window as Frank walks out onto th street and turns toward Broadway. He's gone.  Good. She sits down at her computer.  An expression of anticipa and guilty pleasure as she clicks the mouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we see the logo for America On Line come up and Kathle code name: Shopgirl.  She logs on and the computer makes its little modem noises as the computer dials the access  number and connects and we hear the machine:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome. And we see Kathleen, listening for the words she's waitin to hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got mail. And Kathleen smiles as her mail page comes up:

dialogues.speaker: WE SEE A LIST OF LETTERS
dialogues.text: Big Cash Op: You can make $$$ in your spare time.  OIL MK You can turn $20 into $20,000 THIS REALLY WORKS U CAN DO Maximize your selling ability nowwwww!!!  NY152 Brinkley Kathleen hits the "delete" key and the first three letter all of them junk-mail -- are deleted and drop offscreen. Then she selects the "Read Mail" key for "NY 152 Brinkley

dialogues.speaker: AND THE LETTER COMES UP
dialogues.text: To: Shopgirl  From: NY152  Re: Brinkley
Kathleen starts to read the letter aloud:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brinkley is my dog.  He loves the  streets of New York as much as I do -- And now we hear Kathleen's voice replaced by the voice of 152, a man named JOE FOX --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- although he likes to eat bits of  pizza and bagel off the sidewalk,  and I prefer to buy them.  Brinkley  is a great catcher and was offered a  tryout on the Mets farm team --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dog is sitting on a large green pillow on the floor. Th is BRINKLEY.  The pillow has "Brinkley" embroidered on it Brinkley's master, JOE FOX, a great-looking guy, full of  charm and irony, comes into the kitchen and pours himself some orange juice.  He's half-dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- but he chose to stay with me so  that he could spend 18 hours a day  sleeping on a large green pillow the  size of an inner tube.  Don't you  love New York in the fall?  It makes  me want to buy school supplies.  I  would send you a bouquet of newly- sharpened pencils if I knew your  name and address.  On the other hand,  this not knowing has its charms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmmmhmmm -- Joe's girlfriend PATRICIA EDEN, in Armani head to toe, co into the kitchen and turns on the $2000 espresso machine, which starts grinding beans.  She's carrying the morning  papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm late. (indicating the  newspaper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Random House fired Dick Atkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good riddance.  Murray Chilton died.   Which makes one less person I'm not  speaking to -- (she drains a cup of  espresso as a second  starts to come out  of the machine)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vince got a great review.  He'll be  insufferable.  Tonight,  PEN dinner --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't I just give them money?  That's  the cause?  Free Albanian writers?   I'm for that. Patricia drains another cup of espresso, looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll go.  You're late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I know I know. She tears out of the kitchen and the door slams behind he Hold on Joe, listening as he hears the elevator door open and close on the landing outside.

dialogues.speaker: IT. JOE'S DEN
dialogues.text: As he comes in and sits down at his laptop computer and l on.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Welcome... You've got mail. And as he starts to read his letter, we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like to start my notes to you as  if we're already in the middle of a  conversation.  I pretend that we're  the oldest and dearest friends -- as  opposed to what we actually are,  people who don't know each other's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: names and met in a Chat Room where  we both claimed we'd never been  before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joe, dressed for work, takes the elevator down with hi elevator man CHARLIE.  There's a certain amount of Good  morning, etc., as the elevator goes down and the voice-ov continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will he say today, I wonder.  I  turn on my computer, I wait  impatiently as it boots up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joe comes out of his building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go on line, and my breath catches  in my chest until I hear three little  words: You've got mail. And the camera now pans from 152 Riverside uptown to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear nothing, not even a sound on  the streets of New York, just the  beat of my own heart.  I have mail.   From you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen comes onto Broadway at the corner of 83rd Str and starts downtown. Through a long lens we can see Joe, walking blocks behind her. As Kathleen and Joe make their way down Broadway we see t West Side of Manhattan in the morning.  Mothers and fathe taking their kids to school, people on their way to work, dogs being walked.  School buses picking up kids, bakery  trucks dropping off brown bags of bread in the doorframes unopened restaurants. Kathleen stops at a newsstand, says good morning to the  newsstand dealer, and picks up a New York Times.

Metal grates are pulled up to open flower shops, nail sal the pharmacy, fish store, the Cuban Chinese Restaurant,  Zabar's. Joe stops at the same newsstand.  He buys all the papers the Times, Wall Street Journal, Post and Daily News.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen picks up her coffee, walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen walks down Columbus, we see Joe a block behin her.  She stops to buy flowers and Joe passes her, crosse to the East side of Columbus Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A building under construction, with plywood board coverin the front and wrapping around the corner.  Joe goes to a  side entrance and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen comes around the corner onto 73rd and stops i front of her store, a children's bookstore called "The Sh Around the Corner."  It is an irresistibly inviting store There are twinkle lights in the windows, framing large st animals reading children's books: Madeleine, Good Night M Where the Wild Things Are.  A teddy bear in a pinafore is reading The Stupids Step Out.  Waiting for Kathleen in fr is one of her employees, CHRISTINA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Christina.  It's a beautiful  day.  Isn't it the most beautiful  day? Christina looks up at the sky as if seeing it for the fir time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.  Yeah, sure. Kathleen unlocks the shop and cranks the grate, which ris making a horrible noise.  Two cabs almost collide in fron of the store, with a screech, and one cabdriver starts ye obscenities at the other.  Kathleen unlocks the door to t store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you love New York in the fall?
Christina looks at her puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen turns the CLOSED sign on the door over to read " and she activates the computer system.  She looks around, and we see a small but charming children's bookstore, wit wooden shelves, a tiny area where kids can sit and read,  some charming posters and a glass case full of first edit of the Oz books and Alice In Wonderland, etc.  There's a  playful display of witches, lit with twinkle lights cover with orange pumpkin globes and a sign reading "The Ten Be Witch List"  and a collection of witch books -- "The Lion The Witch and the Wardrobe," "The Witches," "The Wizard o Oz." On the counter is a glass jar full of sugar-free lollipop Kathleen hangs up her coat in the back of the store and  suddenly stops to daydream.  A smile creeps onto her face Christina looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In love?  No.  Yes.  Of course I am.   I'm in love with Frank.  I'm  practically living with Frank.  Do  you think you could get our Christmas  mailers out this week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By Monday I promise.  I have a paper  due Friday.  Now what's going on? (she looks at Kathleen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just going to stand here till  you tell me. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it infidelity if you're involved  with someone on E-mail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you had sex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.  I don't even know  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean cybersex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't do it.  The minute you  do, they lose all respect for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like that.  We just E-mail.   It's really nothing, on top of which  I'm definitely thinking of stopping  because it's getting --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confusing.  But not really.  Because  it's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you meet him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't even remember. (off Christina's look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day I turned thirty I wandered  into the Over Thirty Room for a joke,  sort of and he was there, and we  started chatting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Books.  Music.  How much we both  love New York.  Harmless.  Harmless.   Meaningless. (starts smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bouquets of sharpened pencils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't talk about anything personal.   We made a rule about that.  I don't  know his name, what he does or exactly  where he lives, so it will be really  easy to stop seeing him, because I'm  not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, he could be the next person to  talk into the store.  He could be... (as George walks in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George. GEORGE PAPPAS, in his twenties, one of Kathleen's salespe is a cute guy who has no idea that he's supposed to look the mirror when he gets dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you On Line?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As far as I'm concerned, the Internet  is just another way to be rejected  by a woman. BIRDIE walks in.  She is in her seventies, has white hair and is tiny, like a little sparrow.  She is the store's o employee, having worked there for over forty years, and s as a accountant as well as salesperson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Birdie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you all talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cybersex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to have cybersex once but I  kept getting a busy signal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know.  One Saturday night  I was really depressed about not  having a date, so I thought, no  problemo, I'll go on line and I won't  be lonely, but I couldn't get on,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: there were hundreds of thousands of  people who didn't have dates trying  to get on.  You have to wonder which  is harder, getting a date or getting  On Line when you don't have a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting a date is harder. We hear the bell jingle as TWO WEST SIDE MOTHERS come in  with two KIDS IN STROLLERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the kids)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica and Maia, how are you today? We hear the sound of the garbage truck.  Kathleen goes ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the commercial garbage truck pulls up and TWO GARBAGEM start to load her trash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you forgot to pick up the garbage  last week and I got a ticket.  And  you're late today -- I could have  gotten another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were here, there was no garbage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course there was --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think, I don't want to  pick up garbage?  You think I go up  and down the street picking up  garbage, I'm not going to pick up  yours?  What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Kathleen is standing there, tongue-tied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't even bundle it right, you're  supposed to bundle it and leave it  near the curb, you leave it near the  store and you use cheap garbage bags,  they smear all over the place, and  then I got to pick it up with my  shovel --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Christina, who's helping one of the customers, looks o the window as the harangue continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now you're busting my chops.   You're just another garbage pick-up  to us, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. As Kathleen continues to stand there, speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen comes back into the store.  Christina is ring up a sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy went ballistic on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you told him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly. Another customer enters the store.  The bell jingles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little truck carrying a knife sharpener, its bells ring passes the building under construction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WORKERS, ELECTRICIANS, MASONS, CARPENTERS, etc. in the pr of building what looks like a large store.  Wires hanging everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The electrical contractor called.   His truck hit a deer last night, he  won't be in 'til tomorrow.  The  shelves are late because the shipment  of pine had beetles.  And there's  some question about whether we're  installing the stairs in the right  spot --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Testing one two three four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the electrician here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just told you -- he hit a deer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear nothing.  Not a sound on the  city streets, just the beat of my  own heart.  I think that's the way  it goes.  Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beginning to glean  something)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you and Patricia get engaged?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Engaged?  Are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you liked Patricia --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love Patricia.  Patricia's amazing.   Patricia makes coffee nervous. (suddenly all business)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we still on schedule?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We open two weeks before Thanksgiving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we should announce ourselves  soon.  Tell people we're coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the Upper West Side of  Manhattan.  The minute they hear  they'll be lining up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- to picket --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the big bad --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --chain store --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- that destroys --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- everything we hold dear.  But  we'll seduce them with our square  footage and our deep armchairs and  our amazingly swift checkout lines  and our discounts and our...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the trump card)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- cappuccino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hate us in the beginning, but  we get them in the end.  Meanwhile  we should just put up a sign -- Coming  soon, a Foxbooks Superstore and The  End of Western Civilization As We  Know It.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is in the office with his father, NELSON FOX, and his grandfather, SCHUYLER FOX.  The office has been recently  redecorated; everything is new and a little overdone. On the wall we see the Foxbooks logo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin and I are both a little  concerned about the neighborhood  response -- (suddenly notices the  garish couch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this fabric?  Does it have a  name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money.  Its name is money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gillian selected it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father is getting married again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, great, congratulations, Dad.   Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows?  Why does anyone get  married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that is one reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're a damn fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, Matthew is four.  It would be  nice for him if his parents were  married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabel is eight and I'm not married  to her mother.  I can't even remember  her mother's name. (he laughs merrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a very sad announcement to  make.  City Books on 23rd Street is  going under ... Nelson, Shuyler, and Joe high-five each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another independent bookstore bites  the dust --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On to the next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm buying their entire stock --  architecture, New York history --  for the new store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much are your paying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever it costs, it won't be as  much as this exquisite mohair episode. (indicates the couch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're also going to have a section  on West Side Writers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as a sop to the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect.  It'll keep those West Side  liberal nut pseudo-intellectual  bleeding hearts --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Readers.  They're called readers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't romanticize them.  It'll keep  them from jumping down your throat --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the competition?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One mystery store.  Sleuth, on 86th  and Amsterdam.  And a children's  bookstore.  The Shop Around the  Corner.  Been there forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecilia's store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecilia Kelly, lovely woman.  I think  we might have had a date once.  Or  maybe we just exchange letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wrote her letters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mail.  It was called mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fondly nostalgic and  kidding it slightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stamps.  Envelopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.  I've heard of it.  It was a  means of communication before I was  born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecilia had beautiful penmanship.   She was too young for me, but she  was...  enchanting.  Her daughter  owns it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad for her. As a DECORATOR walks into the office carrying a pile of  upholstered pillows, and Joe turns to look at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome.  You've got mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father is getting married again.   For five years he's been living with  a woman who studied decorating at  Caesar's Palace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen looks up from her book as a butterfly flies thro the subway car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once I read a story about a butterfly  in the subway, and today I saw one.  I couldn't believe it.  It got on at  42nd -- The train comes to a stop.  The butterfly flies out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and got off at 59th, where I assume  it was going to Bloomindale's to buy  a hat that will turn out to be a  mistake.  As almost all hats are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flour truck is unloading flour into a hole in the groun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know that every night a truck  pulls up to H&H Bagels and pumps  about a ton of flour into the ground?   The air is absolutely amazing. As Joe comes around the corner and sees the dust filling air.  It is amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I've read Pride & Prejudice  about 100 times --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joe reads a copy of Pride and Prejudice.  He can't sta it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and every time I read it I worry  that Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy are not  going to get together -- but the  truth is whenever I think about my  favorite book I always think about  the books I read as a child --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen takes a copy of Homer Price off the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever read Homer Price?  My  all-time favorite children's book. She opens it to the illustration of the doughnut machine  that won't stop making doughnuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a doughnut machine in it  that won't stop making doughnuts,  they just keep coming down the chute  just as regular as a clock can tick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been to Krispy Kreme? Joe, eating a doughnut, looks through the window at the h doughnut machine as the doughnuts roll down the chute jus as regular as a clock can tick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a doughnut machine right in  the window that makes 110 dozen  doughnuts an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joe leaves with his morning coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe goes to his painter at work: COMING SOON is as far as he's gotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She enters Starbucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen buys her morning coffee and listens to everyo ordering. We can hear the sounds of Starbucks: "Short decaf cap,"   "Tall mocha latte."  "Grande lowfat regular."  Etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The painter is further along on the sign.  It now reads:

dialogues.speaker: COMING SOON, A FOXBOOKS SU --
dialogues.text: Kathleen walks past the construction site.  She doesn't r pay attention to the sign painter. We see two police cars barreling up 75th Street, followed a television news truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police cars and TV truck barrel uptown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn left onto West 101st and stop in front of an  apartment building on the block.  There are more police c and a horde of television reporters with microphones, etc George emerges from the building as a newscaster broadcas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The body of a woman was found this  morning on the roof of a New York  building... As George comes out of his building into a horde of REPOR with microphones, cameras, etc. and listens to the report who, seeing George, sticks the microphone into his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is a resident of the building.   Your name, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Pappas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see or hear anything unusual  last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I didn't go out. At that moment, George sees a young woman.  This is MERED CARTER.  He is struck dumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The victim was red-haired, about  thirty-five, wearing a jogging suit.   Did you encounter anyone by that  description in the building?  Sir? George hasn't heard a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have there been any wild parties  lately? George doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could it perhaps be one of your  neighbors? George continues to stare at the beautiful woman.  As he  does, she notices him.  She stares back.
The reporter, ignored, finally turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you can see, no one here knows  anything. He continues to stand there, dumbstruck for a moment. Meredith Carter starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George walks along Broadway, past the sign, which now  says: "COMING SOON: A FOXBOOKS SUPERSTORE".  He sees it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen and several CUSTOMERS in the store. George walks in and goes to the back to hang up his coat. Christina is unpacking boxes.  Birdie is at the desk.  Ge looks at Christina meaningfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (totally mystified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coup de foudre. I had one. I  never believed in them, but I just  had one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the thing where you get cold  suddenly, bang?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's the coup de vieux.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coup de foudre is where you get  love suddenly, bang.  A thunderbolt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had that too.  Only I had it in  Seville, where it was called ,el  estruendo de amor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know her name, or anything  about her.  I may never see her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you ever do meet her, you'll  find out all the horrible details,  and that will be that.  She'll turn  out to have pictures of the Virgin  Mary all over the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't care. Kathleen sticks her head into the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can someone help me out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George had a coup de foudre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Christina's making fun of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let her.  I believe in this, I  completely believe in this.  It  happened to Madame Bovary, at least  six times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she was wrong every time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  She was standing  outside my building with the police  and the reporters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What police and reporters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea about that either.   They found her on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dead body.  That's so sad.  But  you fell in love.  That's so great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  One other thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sign is now complete and it says: "Coming soon, just  around the corner.  A Foxbooks Superstore." Kathleen and George and Christina stand there looking at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quel nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has nothing to do with us. It's  big, impersonal, overstocked and  full of ignorant salespeople.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they discount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they don't provide any service.   We do. George and Christina nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen is having lunch with Birdie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So really it's a good development.   You know how in the flower district,  there are all these flower shops in  a row so you can find whatever you  want.  Well, this is going to be the  book district.  If you don't have  it, we do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And vice versa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen in the kitchen, unloading groceries.  Frank is  standing there, plugging in an Olympia Report deluxe Elec typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you are finished with Foxbooks,  the Shop Around the Corner is going  to be responsible for reversing the  entire course of the Industrial  Revolution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is so sweet, Frank.  Thank you.   That is so sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- He holds his arms out.  They hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder,  she notices the  typewriter, breaks  from the hug)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that doing there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to it.  Just listen-- He strikes a key.  Practically swoons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Olympia Report deluxe Electric  Report.  As in gunshot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sound is familiar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen to this. He puts his ear to the typewriter. Kathleen listens too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That whirring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gentle and soothing lullaby of a  piece of machinery so perfect --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where I've heard it before.   I know. She whips a cover off the other typewriter on the table. It's the same machine exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I needed a backup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you have another one at your  apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might, I might.  So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're turning my apartment into a  typewriter museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll stop.  I'll try.  I probably  can't.  I see one and my knees go  weak.  Anyway, what were you starting  to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I was just wondering  about my work and all.  I mean, what  is it I do exactly?  All I really do  is run a bookstore --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you really do is this incredibly  noble thing -- Kathleen nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't know if I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a lone reed. Kathleen looks puzzled. He sticks a piece of paper in the typewriter, starts typi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a lone reed waving in the  breeze standing strong and tall in  the corrupt sands of commerce. He whips the piece of paper out of the typewriter and han it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a lone reed. (tries it on again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a lone reed. Clutching her piece of paper, she wanders into the bathro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the sound of a typewriter begin to clack away in next room. Kathleen walks past her computer, looks at it.  Then she  goes over to the window, looks out at her street at dusk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of schoolgirls in uniform, in two straight lines, walk past with a tall woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes over to the bookshelf and pulls out a copy of  Madeleine by Ludwig Bemelmans and opens it to the illustr of the twelve little girls in two straight lines marching through the streets of Paris.  She looks at it, then look up, lost in thought.  We hear the sound of the computer k

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wonder about my life.  I  lead a small life.  Well, not small,  but circumscribed.  And sometimes I  wonder, do I do it because I like  it, or because I haven't been brave?   So much of what I see reminds me of  something I read in a book, when  shouldn't it be the other way around? And hold on her as she thinks about this. In the other room, we hear Frank typing. Kathleen goes to the computer, turns it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we see Kathleen, through her curtains, a small figure  barely lit by her computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really want an answer.  I  just want to send this cosmic question  out into the void.  So goodnight,  dear void.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drip is a cafe on Amsterdam Avenue with Fifties-style cou and chairs in cozy seating arrangements.  Kathleen is sta at the front counter with Christina, getting drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to the Foxbooks Website and  you can buy anything.  They ship it  to you in a day.  Maybe we should  get a website.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother would never have wanted us  to have a website.  "Every book you  sell is a gift from your heart."   She always said that.
As they walk toward the back of the cafe, Kathleen notice stack of loose-leaf binders on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if they put us out of business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's out of the question.  We're a  fixture in the neighborhood.  We're  practically a landmark. (indicating the binders)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men For Women, Women for Men, Women  for Women -- what is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fill out one of these forms and  they file it in the book and if  someone wants to meet you, they  arrange it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a stupid way to meet someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Compared to the Internet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My little thing on the Internet is  just a lark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's still going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I do not plan to meet him. (indicating the book)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I get the feeling that you  are in here somewhere? Christina flips the book open to her application.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came in here one night and drank  too much coffee and filled one out. (off Kathleen's look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well how am I supposed to meet  someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a runner.  Some day you will  make eye contact with another runner  and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one ever even looks at me.  They  don't.  On top of which, who are  they?  They could like the symphony.   I could never fall in love with  someone who likes to go to the  symphony --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  What are you supposed to do  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit.  You're supposed to sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could never fall in love with anyone  who smokes cigars either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what I hate.  Big fat  legs like stumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I hate that too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The worst, the worst -- I could never,  under any circumstances, love anybody  who had a sailboat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither could I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I had to get up on Saturday morning  knowing that I was about to go down  to the pier and unravel all those  ropes and put on all that sunblock --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that talk about the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then you have to go out on the  boat, and you sail and sail and sail  until you are bored witless, and  then, only then, do they say, let's  turn around and you realize the trip  is only half over, only it's not,  because the wind has changed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hasn't changed.  It's died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then there's more talk about the  wind.  While you just float up and  down trying not to get nauseous.   And when you finally get back, you  have to clean up the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't people have boat maids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  There're all these people  who wouldn't be caught dead polishing  a doorknob in their house but put  them on a boat and they want to rub  down everything in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is on his sailboat.  He is polishing his brass and  whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe -- Joe jumps off the boat onto the dock to greet his  grandfather's daughter ANNABEL, 8, who is coming toward t dock with GILLIAN, his father's overdecorated 32-year-old fiance, her son, MATTHEW, 4, and the Nanny, MAUREEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. (picks up Annabel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabel, how are you today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picks up Matt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, big guy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't I get a hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Gillian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiss me.  I'm going to be your wicked  stepmother.
Joe gives her a peck on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nanny Maureen.  I brought her in  case you couldn't handle the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen's getting a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my own fault.  Never marry a  man who lies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is so wise.  Remember that,  Annabel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She taught Matt to spell his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox. F-O-X.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent, Matt. (to Maureen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good work.  You can have the day  off.  I'll take over from here. (to Gillian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be late for something.   Volunteer work at the Henry Street  Settlement.  Packing bandages for  Bosnian refugees.  A course in Chinese  literature at Columbia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.  I'm having my eggs harvested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a block street fair with little booths, sausage  sandwich concessions, etc.  Annabel and Matt have been to the makeup booth.  Annabel is a cat and Matt is a pirate. Annabel is carrying a goldfish in a baggie as they walk t Broadway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joe, Annabel and Matt walk past.  There's some sort of toy miniature princess in a pointed hat sitting outside t store and a sign lit with twinkle lights: Storybook Lady  today 3:30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen is sitting on a stool reading to a group of CHIL including Annabel and Matt, who are crammed into her stor Joe is watching, along with some PARENTS as Kathleen read from a Roald Dahl book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt is sitting on the floor reading a book.  Kathleen is showing Annabel a copy of a book called Betsy-Tacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is her best friend Tacy, whose  real name is Anastasia, and then in  the next book Betsy and Tacy become  friends with Tib, whose real name, I  am sorry to tell you, is Thelma. In another section of the store: George is showing Joe a first edition of Swiss Family Rob from the glass case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The illustrations are hand-tipped,  which is why --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It costs so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's why it's worth so much. Joe smiles and turns to see Kathleen and Annabel at a who shelf of Betsy-Tacy books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want all of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That might be an awful lot for your  dad to buy at one time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dad gets me all the books I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking over at Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's very nice of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not my dad.  That's my nephew --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't really think that's your  nephew -- As Joe approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true.  Annabel is my aunt.   Aren't you, Aunt Annabel? Annabel nods solemnly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Matt is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me guess. (to Matt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you his uncle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His grandfather? Annabel and Matt start giggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His great-grandfather?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting with glee)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabel is my grandfather's daughter.   And Matt is my father's son.  We are  an American family. He smiles at Kathleen, who finds herself smiling back. Annabel suddenly sneezes. Kathleen takes a handkerchief from her sleeve.  It's an o fashioned hankie that's embroidered.
She offers it to Annabel, who instead wipes her nose with her hand and then looks at the handkerchief, a little puz

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handkerchief.  Oh my, do children  not even know what handkerchiefs  are?  A handkerchief is a Kleenex  you don't throw away.  My mother  embroidered it for me -- you see?   My initials and a daisy, because  daisies are my favorite flower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orchids are my favorite flower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what else children don't  know?  They don't know what a  telephone booth is? Joe is looking at Kathleen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen Kelly.  I own this store.   And you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe.  Just call me Joe. (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take these books. He gets the one Matt is reading.  And the two other Kathl has gotten for Annabel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are wonderful books.  As Annabel  gets older the characters in the  books do, too. (to Annabel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can grow up with Betsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to come back again,  aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is why we're never going to go  under.  Our customers are loyal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (by way of explanation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're opening a Foxbooks around  the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foxbooks!  My Daddy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently putting his  hand over her mouth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- likes to buy at discount.  Don't  tell anyone that, Annabel, it's  nothing to be proud of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's amazing.  You can spell fox.   Can you spell dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt, look at this dinosaur book.   Wouldn't you like a dinosaur book?   Annabel, maybe you could read this  to Matt while I wrap things up here. (moves them to a  corner, to them  quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, read, and don't listen to  anything I say. Returns to counter and gives Kathleen some cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the dinosaur book too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world is not driven by discounts,  believe me.  I've been in business  forever.  I started helping my mother  here after school when I was six  years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to watch her, and it wasn't  that she was selling books, it was  that she was helping people become  whoever they were going to turn out  to be.  When you read a book as a  child it becomes part of your identity  in a way that no other reading in  your life does. (stops herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I've gotten carried away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have, and you've made me feel... He can't finish the sentence.  He looks at her and sees,  behind her on the shelf, a picture of a woman who is  unmistakably Kathleen's mother, with a young Kathleen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enchanting, your mother was  enchanting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was.  How did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway.  She left the store to me,  and I'm going to leave it to my  daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old is your daughter now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm not married.  But eventually. She smiles at Joe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Foxbooks can...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him his books)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ready?
Annabel and Matt join him at the counter.  Kathleen gives them each a lollipop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, Kathleen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Annabel.  Bye, Matt.  What  about cat?  Can you spell cat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someplace like the auditorium at the Museum of Broadcasti PATRICIA EDEN, Joe's girlfriend, who is the editor-in-chi of a New York publishing house called Eden Books, is stan at a podium at a sales conference.  In the audience are s reps, wholesalers, etc.  There's a screen behind her with pictures of the authors being flashed on it as she speaks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now, the book you've all been  waiting for, the book it's been my  dreams to publish.  The legendary  Veronica Grant has written her memoirs -- There's a burst of applause as a photograph of Veronica G flashes on screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and I'm happy to report it is  just crammed with tragedy. (she laughs gaily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just kidding, but seriously, it's  all here: poverty, addiction, divorce,  tracheotomies -- We see pictures of Veronica at eight with her sharecroppe family, Veronica at 14 with her first child, Veronica wit series of husbands, Veronica in a wheelchair, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- her third husband beat her up,  hip replacement, and an amazing face  lift where all the injected fat fell  to her chin. Now we see a blow-up of the book's jacket, with a picture Veronica on it and the title: "Am I Rising from Ashes, or Did I Just Forget to Dust?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This book is fabulous.  And even if  it weren't, it would sell like crazy,  because Veronica is going to plug it  to death on every talk show in  America.  This book... Patricia bursts into tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  I can't talk about it  without crying.  Veronica and I have  so much in common -- well, not all  the sad parts -- but we were both  famous by the time we were 29 and,  believe me, that's rough. (wipes her nose with  a Kleenex, pulling  herself together)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I just want to say that I'm  especially thrilled to be publishing  it.  Veronica lives in my building  and we met in the elevator.  By the  time we had traveled from the eighth  floor to the first, we had a deal.   First printing: one million copies. Everyone applauds enthusiastically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patricia is leaving, still surrounded by colleagues and s reps congratulating her.  She is the soul of graciousness Her assistant, Sarah, comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a dentist appointment in  twenty minutes.  So you should leave  soon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's my car number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Car?  You didn't say anything about  a car --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you an idiot?  Of course I need  a car.  God! She walks toward the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patricia in the pouring rain, trying to hail a cab.  She  spots one across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taxi!  Taxi!  Taxi! She whistles -- a longshoreman's whistle. The cab makes a U-turn, but instead of stopping for Patri it stops about twenty feet ahead for a MAN in an overcoat who gets into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me -- what are you doing?   This is my taxicab. (to the driver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take him.  I am telling you  right now, and I am memorizing your  number, don't take him. (to the man)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going uptown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in.  I'll drop you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the cab turns onto Eighth Avenue, starts uptown. Patricia is dialing her cell phone.  She's elaborately  ignoring the man who stole her cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Veronica, it's Patricia, you should  have been there, it was unbelievable,  we're going to sell truckloads of  your book.  Call me. She hangs up, folds up the phone, puts it back in her pur as the cab moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you an editor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a rabbi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God, I said fuck to a rabbi.   I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you don't mind my asking, but  are you Jewish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should come to our temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not really religious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I am surprised, you seem like a  very religious person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are at West End Avenue and 83rd  Street.  Every Friday night, we have  a joyous time, everyone dancing,  everyone singing.  Also some wisdom.   Perhaps you have heard of us, we are  known as The Singles Temple. He smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a very good place to calm down. The cab stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, look, I am already here.  Very  nice to meet you. (gives the cabbie  money)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take this woman to her destination. He gets out.  Closes the door.  A beat too late:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank comes up the stoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen is dressed up for a party. Frank walks in, looks meaningfully at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw him.  I actually saw him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it.  I saw William  Spungeon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought he was in Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's in Mexico, but today he  was in New York.  The most brilliant  and reclusive novelist in the history  of the world is here, in this  neighborhood.  He may be living on  this very block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you see him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was on the subway --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and this musician got onto the  train -- Frank is sitting on the subway, reading the Village Voice The door between the cars opens and a man playing the cla enters the car. No one looks up except Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and I suddenly saw him, sitting  directly across from me doing the  crossword puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you know it was him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looked exactly the same as his  high school yearbook picture, which  happens to be the last photograph  ever taken of him. Frank takes out his billfold on the subway, pulls out a p of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Frank unfolds a newspaper clipping of a yearbook pictu of William Spungeon at 17. Frank compares the photo of Spungeon with the person sitt across the way.  They don't look remotely alike except th the boy in the picture and the man on the subway are both wearing the same style glasses. The subway stops at 79th Street, and William Spungeon get off. Frank follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Frank comes out of the subway station and looks around

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I followed him. Frank sees Spungeon cross 79th.  He follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank follows Spungeon, who hurries into H&H Bagels passi a HOMELESS MAN holding a paper cup at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went into H&H and bought a bagel  with everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Spungeon leaves the store, passing the paper cup, whic we now realize that Frank, in dark glasses, is holding. Spungeon drops his newspaper in a garbage container.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dropped his crossword into the  garbage and I rescued it. Frank plucks the puzzle from the trashcan, follows Spunge

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spungeon at the counter in the shoe store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he went into a sporting good  store and bought tube socks, 6 pair  for $7.99. We see Frank, peeking out at him from behind a stack of  running pants.  Suddenly he's distracted by a couple of  joggers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Spungeon and tube socks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I don't want to dwell on  it. Frank looks back at the counter.  Spungeon's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then I lost him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank waves the crossword puzzle in front of Kathleen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what this is worth? He takes an empty instant-frame from the closet, puts the puzzle into it and sets it next to the typewriters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the two of them eat dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I was thinking as I was trailing  him was that eventually I would have  the courage to say hello to him, you  know, not in a horrible, intrusive  or slavering fan-slash-acolyte kind  of way, but more like, "Hi."  "How  ya doing?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Have you ever thought about trading  up in the sock area?"  Who knows,  maybe he's read my work -- and then  we'd become friends, and eventually  I'd introduce him to you -- you know  how much he loves children's books,  there's a whole long section in  Relativity's Smile about The Wizard  of Oz -- and then maybe he'd come  out of hiding so he could help save  the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Foxbooks.  I mean, if things  got tough, he could help rally support --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's never going to get to that.   The store is fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk along after dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even know why you would say  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither do I.  It just flew out of  my mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's enough business for us all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they go up in an elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, we're fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're more than fine, you're  absolutely fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A publication party for an author named VINCE MANCINI.  A mix of book people, journalists and various other media f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Vince.  Congratulations.  You  know Kathleen Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess who I saw today on the subway?   William Spungeon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought he was in Mexico. They start chatting. Across the room, Joe is with Patricia, who is telling two other people the story of meeting the rabbi in the taxica Joe looks over and sees Kathleen.  He suddenly looks stri Shifts his position so Kathleen can't see his face, but s a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you get me another drink,  sweetie?  I'm all out. (continues chattering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then the rabbi says, "It's a very  good place to calm down."  Isn't  that hysterical? They all laugh.  Joe moves over to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolut on the rocks. As he is waiting, Kathleen comes up next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A white wine, please. (very friendly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember me, from the bookstore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I remember you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your aunt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  She's good. (gets his drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to deliver this.  I have a  very thirsty date.  She's part camel. Kathleen laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe.  It's Joe, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're Kathleen. Joe vanishes into the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you were talking to  Joe Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Fox?  As in -- She can't even finish the sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is standing at a table of food, his back to the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox?  Your last name is Fox? Joe spins around, looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I didn't realize.  I didn't  know who you -- (she trails off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- were with. (quoting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I didn't know who you were with."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's from the Godfather.  When the  movie producer realizes that Tom  Hagen is the emissary of Vito Corleone -- Kathleen is staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- just before the horse's head ends  up in his bed never mind --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were spying on me, weren't you?   You probably rented those children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I spy on you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am your competition.  Which you  know perfectly well or you would not  have put up that sign saying "Just  around the Corner."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entrance to our store is around  the corner.  There is no other way  to say it.  It's not the name of our  store, it's where it is.  You don't  own "around the corner."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next thing you'll be using twinkle  lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twinkle lights?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little white Christmas lights that  twinkle.  I use them in my window  and on all my displays, as if you  didn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, the reason I came into your  store is that I was spending the day  with Annabel and Matt.  I like to  buy them a present when I see them  because I'm one of those guys who  likes to buy his way into the hearts  of children who are his relatives.   There was only one place to buy  children's books in the neighborhood --  although that will not always be the  case, and it was yours, and it is a  charming little bookstore.  You  probably sell $250,000 worth of book  a year --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in the book business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in the book business --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see, and we're the Price Club.   Only instead of a ten-gallon can of  olive oil for $3.99 that won't even  fit into your kitchen cabinet, we're  selling cheap books.  Me a spy. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.  And I managed to get my  hands on a secret printout of the  sales figures of a bookstore so  inconsequential and yet full of its  own virtue that I was instantly  compelled to rush over and check it  out for fear it would drive me out  of business -- Kathleen stares at him.  She's speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? (off her look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Kathleen shakes her head. Frank turns up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.  I'm Frank Navasky --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Joe Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Fox?  Inventor of the Superstore,  enemy of the mid-list novel, destroyer  of City Books -- tell me something:  How do you sleep at night? Patricia joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I use a wonderful over-the-counter  drug, Ultrasom.  Don't take the whole  thing, just half, and you will wake  up without even that tiniest hangover.   You're Frank Navasky, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your last piece in the Independent,  the one about Anthony Powell, was  brilliant.  I'm Patricia Eden, Eden  Books.  Joe, this man is the greatest  living expert on Julius and Ethel  Rosenberg --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is Kathleen Kelly -- Kathleen glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You liked my piece.  God, I'm  flattered.  You know you write these  things and you think someone's going  to mention them and then the whole  week goes by and the phone doesn't  ring, and you think Oh, God, I'm a  fraud, a failure --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what's always fascinated me  about Julius and Ethel Rosenberg is  how old they looked when they were  really just our age. Everyone is stopped dead by this observation and looks at Patricia, who smiles at them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Frank)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so happy to have finally met  you.  We will talk.  Have you ever  thought about doing a book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sure, it's passed through my head.   Something really relevant for today  like the Luddite movement in 19th  century England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patricia --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen and Frank get into bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really like Patricia Eden.  She's  a very nice person. Kathleen doesn't respond.  Frank turns out the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She needs educating, that's all. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's hopelessly driven by money and  power, but there's a hope for anyone  who's that familiar with my work -- On Kathleen, as she turns away from Frank and lies there, eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joe and Patricia get into bed.  Brinkley is already on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no idea that Frank Navasky was  so down-to-earth. Joe doesn't respond.  Patricia turns out the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You read his stuff, you think he's  going to be so obscure and abstruse. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's always talking about Heidigger  and Foucault and I have no idea what  any of it's about, really. Joe gets up.  Brinkley follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not really tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe writes on his computer.  Brinkley on the floor next t him. And cut between Joe and his computer screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you ever feel you become the worst  version of yourself?  That a Pandora's  Box of all the secret hateful parts --  your arrogance, your spite, your  condescension -- has sprung open.   Someone provokes you, and instead of  just smiling and moving on, you zing  them.  Hello, it's Mr. Nasty.  I'm  sure you have no idea what I'm talking  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen reads the end of Joe's letter. Kathleen hits the Reply key and starts to type:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you mean and I'm  completely jealous.  What happens to  me when I'm provoked is that I get  tongue-tied.  My mind goes blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I spend all night tossing and  turning trying to think of what I  should have said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be wonderful if I could  pass all my zingers to you and then  I would never behave badly and you  could behave badly all the time and  we'd both be happy?  On the other  hand, I must warn you that when you  finally have the pleasure of saying  the thing you mean to say at the  moment you mean to say it, remorse  inevitably follows.  Do you think we  should meet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen stares at Joe's letter in her computer. She's frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet?  Omigod. She sits staring at the letter.  She has no idea what to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the iron gates on all the stores start to open, just t way we saw them open in the opening sequence of the movie The pharmacy.  The optician.  The cosmetics supply store. The video store. And now, finally, we see the new grate on the new Foxbook Superstore start to open upwards.  This is the finest gra on Broadway, no question of it.  It's electric and almost soundless.  We see a sign saying, OPENING DAY.  35% OFF O ALL BEST-SELLERS. People on the street notice the store.  One walks in... CAMERA follows him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inside is beautiful.  Gleaning staircase, a cafe,  comfortable chairs to sit, a bank of cashiers, everyone d out in gray alligator shirts with a fox where the alligat should be, a rope for the checkout line, and seven cash  registers with seven cashiers.  Of course, books, books,  books, as far as the eye can see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The store is jam-packed.  Joe with his father Nelson, his grandfather Schuyler, and Kevin, the store manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No pickets, no demonstrations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neighborhood loves us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're wondering where we've been  all these years.  They're wondering  how they ever did without it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a hit. They admire their own store, walk through the downstairs start up the staircase to the second floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the children's book department?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's early yet.  School isn't out.   And there's that children's bookstore  nearby --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecilia's store --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her daughter's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll crush it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was enchanting.
And as they walk on upstairs, several mothers with childr come up the stairs behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little group of children dressed as Pilgrims walk down street as Kathleen comes around the corner to buy her mor paper.  Joe is at the newsstand.  She turns and pretends be staring at a wall until he finishes buying his paper a walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it's a good idea for  us to meet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is putting sugar into his coffee at the sugar counter Kathleen comes in.  He pretends he didn't see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love our relationship.  There's a  lot going on in the day-to-dayness  of my life and there's something  magical...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Kathleen and George at the end of the day, countin the receipts.  Birdie is using a calculator to total them Christina is shelving books.  There are Thanksgiving  decorations -- cardboard turkeys and pilgrims, books on  colonists like Myles Standish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and thrilling about this island  in cyberspace I have with you.  SO  PLEASE DON'T ASK ME AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About $1200 less than the same week  last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That could be a fluke, right? They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their store is new.  It's a novelty.   But it will all shake out.  Do you  think I should put up more twinkle  lights?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lovely idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if we have to fold?  I'll never  find another part time job and I  won't be able to pay the rent and  I'll have to move to Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The joy of rent control.  Six room  for $450 a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know.  You've told us a million  times.  I can't believe you're  bringing it up at a time like this.   It's like bragging because you're  tall.  Birdie never brags about her  rent and she pays even less than  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten rooms.  I just rattle around  from one to the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, guys.  We are not going to fold. The door opens, and Meredith Carter, the woman George had swooned over in front of his building, walks in. George stares, frozen in place, as she walks up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Pappas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (I have died and gone  to heaven)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flashing her badge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective Carter, 23rd precinct.   I'd like to ask you a few questions.
Kathleen suddenly sees George, following Meredith out of store.  He's in a complete daze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George?  Where are you going? He goes out the door. LAURA MARGULIES, a well-known children's book author, ent as George leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen, are you surviving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura!  We're so excited about your  new book.  When should we schedule  your signing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's being published in January.   Are you going to be in business in  January?  I'm so worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're doing great, aren't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No difference whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God.  Well, you know you can  count on me.  For anything, support,  rallies.  Picket lines.  We can get  the Times to write something.  Or  that nut in the Independent --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What nut in the Independent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Navasky.  This is just the  sort of thing that would outrage  him. She smiles brightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Meredith are sitting in a booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pappas, I'm investigating the  murder of the woman found on the  roof of your building.  Do you live  alone there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I live alone?  Yes I do.  Do you  live alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. George takes her hand in his and looks at it as if it wer the eighth wonder of the world.  He starts stroking it,  caressing it... Meredith pulls it away.  A beat.  Then she gives it right back to him.  He continues stroking.  They stare at each  other.  He puts her fingers into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overwhelmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. She utters a little moan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
