dialogues.text: They come into the apartment.  She throws herself into hi arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Christina runs, desperately trying to make eye contact with men running in the opposite direction.  No one will  look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is mobbed -- the usual crush the night before  Thanksgiving. Kathleen, pushing a shopping cart, is trying to wedge her way through the crowd in the cheese department.

As she reaches across three people to grab some Brie, she sees Joe walk into the store.  Quickly, she turns her bac so he can't see her. She stands there frozen.  A beat... Peeks around, doesn't see him anywhere.  Cranes her neck  this way and that.  No Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen, now wearing dark glasses but looking not at all disguised, looks around and spots a short line and makes beeline for it. At that moment, Joe comes from the Appetizing Department gets on the line she was heading for. Panicked, Kathleen retreats onto another line and stands  with her back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CASHIER totals up Kathleen's purchases and Kathleen h over her credit card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a Cash Only line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cash Only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Omigod, I only have a credit card.   Is that okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it's not okay, there's a  sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the person behind  her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't have cash. "She doesn't have cash" is repeated all the way down the  line.
Joe turns to see what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get on another line, lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you need some money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't need any money.  Thank  you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get on another line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. (off her nametag, big  smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose. Great name.  Rose, this is  Kathleen, I'm Joe, and this is a  credit card machine.  Happy  Thanksgiving. Rose just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it's your turn to say happy  Thanksgiving back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy Thanksgiving back. Joe looks at her, winks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mississippi is a hard word to spell.   How do you spell it?  I-T. (big smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now take this credit card and put it  through the machine, zip zip. The cashier, completely charmed, takes Kathleen's credit  card. Kathleen is appalled. Everyone on the line signs irritably and audibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy Thanksgiving. As Kathleen signs the charge slip and the cashier  exasperatedly starts to put her groceries into a bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An elegant East Side apartment.  Schuyler, his youngish F wife, YVETTE, Nelson, Gillian and their child Matt, and J are sitting and listening as Annabel sings Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun'll come up tomorrow, bet  your bottom dollar that tomorrow,  there'll be sun -- Joe is on a loveseat with Matt.  Gillian lifts Matt up, s down in his place next to Joe and plunks Matt into her la Nelson is already seated in a chair in front of the loves and can't see her without turning around. As she continues singing, Gillian moves her hand next to  Joe's leg.  Joe edges away.  He looks around the room, se Nanny Maureen standing behind the couch.  He stands, offe her his seat.  She sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A much more informal Thanksgiving dinner. We see the left on a sideboard near a round table in Kathleen's living ro Kathleen, Frank, Birdie, Christina, George and George's n girlfriend, Meredith and TWO OTHER FRIENDS are standing a the upright piano.  Birdie is playing a Christmas song, a everyone is singing. As the singing continues, over, we cut to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Christmas decorations and twinkle lights go into t window. Birdie walks by the store.  She stops to look at the cust inside, and then notices a sign in the window:
"Book Signing January 10 - Best Selling Children's Author Laura Margulies."  There's a picture of Laura Margulies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen is in the window decorating a little tree with l decorations from a box.  Two people are carrying a tree h there's the sound of church bells. Kathleen looks up as a couple of people walk past the sto carrying Foxbooks shopping bags. Then she unwraps a pair of ruby slipper ornaments, and as she starts to hang them on the tree we hear the sound of computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is such an odd Christmas.  I  find myself missing my mother, who's  been dead for ten years.  New York  at Christmas is so loaded with all  the things we used to do --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Young Kathleen, dressed in a little velvet dress, sits the audience next to her mother watching the ballet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- going to the Nutcracker --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- ice skating at Rockefeller Center,  where I was knocked into a 6-year- old maniac -- A SIX-YEAR-OLD BOY knocks into her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, watch out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me watch out, why don't you watch  out?  I'm not sliding around like a  baby.  You think I come here to skate  with babies? Young Kathleen's jaw drops and she stands there tongue-ti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My first experience as a speechless  person.
Her mother skates up and takes her hand.  The boy skates  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always miss my mother at Christmas,  but somehow it's worse this year  since I need some advice from her. And we hear the sound of another computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he replies to Kathleen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother took me ice skating too --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a little boy, YOUNG JOE, 8, skate past holding  someone's hand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- although my mother did not skate.   The nanny skated -- And we now see JOE'S NANNY, a young Sonja Henie, who sudd peels off into a series of triple lutzes, as JOE'S MOTHER absently reads a copy of Vogue in the spectators' section

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I was in the Nutcracker. We see the stage now.  There's Young Joe, among the child at the Christmas party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So was my nanny. As JOE'S NANNY #2 pirouettes past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different nanny.  By the way, I'm  surprised you aren't a writer.   Although you probably are a writer  and don't know it.  Are you a writer  and I don't know it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Joe, at the dinner table with his father.  A wide s of a big room with a huge table and servants.
Joe looks very small at the table as he eats his soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother died when I was ten.  I  was staying with my father, who is  not famous for intimacy, and whose  way of breaking the news of her death  was to tell me she would not be coming  to pick me up as usual.  It was a  car accident, and I don't know where  she was going or who she was with,  and I assume what I owe her is my  tendency to cover almost any emotion  with a joke.  A useful gift, unless  you want to know what you're feeling.   She was very beautiful.  People toss  that word around a lot, but my mother  was. The camera moves closer to the dining table.  We see that tears are rolling down little Joe's cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe stops typing.  He is surprised to find his eyes water A moment of confusion as he cannot believe he has moved  himself to tears.  Shakes his head, shakes the emotion of Starts typing again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ancient history.  So what kind of  advice do you need?  Can I help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen in bed with her laptop reading Joe's letter. She starts to type a response. Suddenly there's harp arpeggio and an Instant Message fla on screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a gut feeling you would be on  line now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is in bed with his laptop.  And cut back and forth be them and their computer screens as they type Instant Mess to one another.  Possible split screens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can give you advice.  I'm great at  advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you can help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it about love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My business is in trouble.  My mother  would have something wise to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a brilliant businessman.  It's  what I do best.  What's your business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No specifics, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minus specifics, it's hard to help.   Except to say, go to the mattresses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's from The Godfather.  It means  you have to go to war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Godfather? She starts to type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it with men and The Godfather?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Godfather is the I Ching.  The  Godfather is the sum of all wisdom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Godfather is the answer to any  question.  What should I pack for my  summer vacation?  "Leave the gun,  take the cannoli."  What day of the  week is it? "Maunday, Tuesday,  Thursday, Wednesday." And the answer  to your question is "Go to the  mattresses."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're at war.  "It's not personal,  it's business.  It's not personal  it's business."  Recite that to  yourself every time you feel you're  losing your nerve.  I know you worry  about being brave, this is your  chance.  Fight.  Fight to the death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patricia comes in as Joe is waiting for Kathleen's respon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look what I bought. Joe types "Ciao" and signs off.  Looks up to see Patricia showing him a Plexiglas menorah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just passing this store on  Columbus Avenue and it caught my  eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Menorah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't look like a Menorah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I don't know what came over  me.  I don't even celebrate Hanukkah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen logs off, Frank comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, I've decided to go to the  mattresses.  Do you think it would  be a gigantic conflict of interest  if you wrote something about us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's January.  The store is more crowded than we've seen Frank is there with several copies of the Independent.  T phone is ringing off the hook.  Christina and George are  fielding calls.  Birdie is reading Frank's article.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Kathleen Kelly and her mother Cecilia  Kelly have raised your children.  If  this precious resource is killed by  the cold cash cow of Foxbooks, it  will not only be the end of Western  civilization as we know it, but the  end of something even dearer: our  neighborhood as we know it.  Save  the Shop Around the Corner and you  will save your own soul."  Frank,  that's charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it's a little over the  top?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just say thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to Kathleen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Channel 2's outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen is primping in a tiny wall mirror.  She takes a  deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the other room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Village Voice is coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Omigod. Frank sticks his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in shock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God. It is God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen comes out of the storage room. William Spungeon is standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm William Spungeon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very pleased to meet you.  I'm  Kathleen Kelly. Frank is practically levitating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew your mother.  Although she  knew me only as W.  That enormous  bookstore is obscene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Frank Navasky.  I carry your  picture in my wallet. He pulls it out.  Spungeon looks at him like he's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've organized pickets.  Channel 13  is doing a special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be glad to talk to the press if  it's all right with you.  They've  been trying to interview me for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The press?  I'm the press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd allow that?  For me?  For the  store?  That's incredible.  Although  you wouldn't have to be photographed.   I respect that.  If it's television,  they could just put one of those  blurry dots in front of your face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to the TV  crew)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're waiting for you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know all your books.  Phaelox the  gnome, the little man who comes from  nowhere... and is going nowhere... (quoting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Where did you come from?"  "Nowhere."  "Where are you going?"  "Nowhere."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool it.  I'm starting to break out  in hives. (to Kathleen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's my phone number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no idea William Spungeon had a  phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adios. He gives a little wave and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is historic. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you realize what I've done?  By  writing that piece, do you realize?   I've brought William Spungeon in  from the cold. Holy shit.  I am  completely amazing. At that moment a TV REPORTER sticks her head into the sto

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen Kelly? Kathleen takes a deep breath, walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: CHANNEL 2 TV REPORTER
dialogues.text: Are you ready, Miss Kelly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luca Brasi sleeps with the fishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind.  I'm ready.  Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here in front of the Shop Around  the Corner, the famous West Side  children's bookstore now on the verge  of having to close its doors because  the big bad wolf, Foxbooks, has opened  only a few hundred feet away, wooing  customers with its sharp discounts  and designer coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have to have discounts and  lattes, because most of the people  who work there have never read a  book. And pull back now to reveal that we're in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five TV sets are on, over adjoining treadmills, Joe and K are on two of the treadmills, walking and watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not as nice as she seems on  television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've met her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's kind of a pill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's probably not as attractive as  she seems on television either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she's beautiful.  But a pill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't feel bad about basically  destroying her livelihood not to  mention her legacy not to mention  her raison d'etre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not personal --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  Exactly. They look up at the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe onscreen, with a super: Joe Fox, Vice-President Foxbo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sell cheap books.  Sue me.  I sell  cheap books, and as a result -- listen  to this, because it's really bad -  more people can buy books. The show immediately cuts back to the newscaster. On Joe and Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (outraged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not all I said.  I said -- I  can't believe those bastards -- I  said we were great, I said people  can come and sit and read for hours  and no one bothers them, I said we  stock 150,000 titles, I showed them  the New York City section.  I said  we were a goddamn piazza where people  could mingle and mix and be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A piazza?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was eloquent.  Shit.  It's just  inevitable, isn't it?  People are  going to want to turn her into Joan  of Arc --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and you into Attila the Hun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it's not me personally, it's  more like it's the company --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the television)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I have to say, I have met Joe  Fox, who owns Foxbooks, and I have  heard him compared his store to a  Price Club and the books in it to  cans of olive oil. On Joe, reacting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small rally is taking place, with picket signs.  Kathle is standing on a small speaker's platform, along with the Borough President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother used to say to me that  every book you sell is a gift from  the heart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As 20 CHILDREN march in front of the store, holding littl makeshift picket signs and singing songs.  "One, two, thr four, we don't want this Superstore." Customers go right through the line and into the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can hear the pickets marching and singing outside -- although the store is full of customers anyway.  The Fox Joe, Nelson and Schuyler -- are sitting in the cafe. Nelson is holding a copy of a weekly newspaper, which has the old high-school yearbook picture of William Spungeon the front page and a headline: William Spungeon Emerges f Hiding to Support Bookstore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this Spungeon anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've never heard of him.  And  neither has anyone else in this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we see SIDNEY-ANN STRONGIN, a young and attractive PBS talk show hostess for a show called Inside Media.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The New York Literary world was  shocked this week when William  Spungeon, the most famously reclusive  author since J.D. Salinger, announced  that he was coming out of hiding  because of his loyalty to a small  children's bookstore on the West  Side of Manhattan.  Discussing this  tonight is a man I happen to think  of as one of this city's most  underappreciated assets, Frank  Navasky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This all happened because of you,  didn't it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I knew William Spungeon loved  children's books so I wrote a  provocative column --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your specialty. Frank laughs.  Sidney-Ann laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it kind of smoked him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she and Frank watch the television show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Technologically speaking, the world's  out of hand.  Take the VCR.  The  whole idea of a VCR is that it makes  it possible for you to tape what's  on television while you're out of  the house.  But the whole point of  being out of the house is so you can  miss what's on television.  Radio.   Now there's a medium I can get behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're on television... and  you're good at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Another little moment between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bookstore.  Tell us about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you planning to collect radios?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I should?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shop Around the Corner is a true  New York treasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As are you.  I'd love to have you  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any time.  Are we done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I just want to say that the  only show I do watch is yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appalled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Omigod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I was just being polite.  Okay,  I admit, I slobbered all over her.
The show continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we see Kathleen flip the open sign to closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is talking to Kathleen and Birdie, who is toting u the week's receipts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I can't decide whether to put  sausages into the meat sauce or just  chopped meat.  Last time I made it,  Detective Carter and I never even  sat down to dinner because -- (he makes some sort  of hand gesture  indicating that sex  prevented them from  dining)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and last night, I made margaritas  in the blender, and I took the ice  cube and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spare us. George goes out the door. Birdie looks at Kathleen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me.  Not the slightest  difference? Birdie can't bring herself to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could that be?  All this publicity  and not one bit of difference?  Oh  Birdie, what am I going to do?  What  would Mom have done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's ask her. She opens the locket hanging around her neck.  There's a  picture of Kathleen's mother inside it.  Birdie holds the locket up to her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecilia, what should we do?
Birdie holds the locket to her ear and listens.  A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birdie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhh. (after a beat, shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has no idea, but she thinks the  window display is lovely.  Good night  dearie. Birdie smiles and picks up her shopping bag, goes out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's starting to rain.  Kathleen lowers the grate over th store.  As she turns to walk away, William Spungeon steps her path out of the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my goodness, hello.  What are you  doing here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loitering.  Lurking.  Skulking.   Stalking. He laughs.  So does she.  Dramatically, he whips out an  umbrella and opens it over the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  But I'm a wreck. He touches her cheek suddenly.  Kathleen starts.  Then he blows on his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eyelash.  It's gone. Kathleen relaxes.  They start walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you writing another book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in the home stretch.  I'll be  done in approximately six more years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I discount?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about a man on a quest for  knowledge who meets a woman he cannot  resist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I discount I have to fire someone  because I can't discount with this  overhead but whom could I fire?  I  couldn't fire anyone. Spungeon suddenly puts his hand through Kathleen's hair. She stops, frozen in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have your mother's hair.  Thick,  wild, the color of Nebraska wheat. He grabs her and tries to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?  Let me go. He backs her into a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it.  Are you crazy? She kicks him in the shins, wiggles free and runs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you change your mind, you can E- mail me.  Hermit@AOL.com.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mail form says "To:" and Kathleen types in "NY 152". The form says "Re:" and Kathleen types in:  "Advice"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain is falling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need help.  Do you still want to  meet me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain is falling. We hear the sound of the computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Where?  When?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, Kathleen and Christina in the shop.  Kathleen is  buying more lollipops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're meeting in a public place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well don't go anywhere with him.   Don't even go out to the street with  him afterwards.  Get a dial cab to  just sit there and wait for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you tell Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But did you tell him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's away.  At the 32nd anniversary  of the Chicago Seven trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's gone to a place where there  are no phones.  Do you even know  this guy's name? Kathleen shakes her head no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're going to meet him in a  bar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a bar.  That place on 83rd with  the cheesecake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he will wear a flower in his  lapel, and you will be carrying a  copy of Anna Karenina with a rose in  it. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Anna Karenina.  Pride and  Prejudice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joe and Kevin walk out of the store and start downtown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose she's carrying a copy of a  book with a flower in it. Joe doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which Jane Austen is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pride and Prejudice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She could be a real dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  Look, I'll just stay ten  minutes.  I'll say hello.  Drink a  cup of coffee and split.  I'm outta  here. He looks at Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk me there, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the two men walk toward Cafe Lalo, the European cafe o West 83rd Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if she has a really high, squeaky  voice?  I hate that.  It reminds me  of those mice in Cinderella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What mice in Cinderella?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus-gus and oh shit, I can't remember  the other one.  Why am I compelled  to meet her?  I'm just ruining a  good thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're taking it to the next level.   I always do that.  I always take a  relationship to the next level, and  if it works okay I take it to the  next level after that, until I can  finally get to the level where it  becomes absolutely necessary for me  to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to stay long anyway.   I already said that, didn't I.   Christ.  I'm a total wreck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe stops and looks at Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin, this woman is the most adorable  creature I have ever come in contact  with.  If she turns out to be even  as good-looking as a mailbox, I will  be crazy not to turn my life upside  down and marry her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She could be a real dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a total panic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just go to the window and check her  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're pathetic. Kevin goes to the window and looks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Kevin in front. Kevin looks in the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a beautiful, whoa, a very  beautiful girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But no book.  Let me see, let me  see...  Wait a minute.  There's a  book with a flower, so it must be  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does she look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a waiter blocking, I can't  see her face.  He's serving her a  cup of tea and she's putting in three  spoonfuls of sugar --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why shouldn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reason.  Unless she has  hypoglycemia.  Oh, he's moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you see her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And? --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clearly frustrated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's very pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is.  I knew she would be.  She  had to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks... I would say she has a  little of the coloring of that  Kathleen Kelly person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen Kelly of the bookstore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?  You said you thought she  was attractive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?  Who cares about Kathleen  Kelly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you don't like Kathleen  Kelly, I can tell you right now you  ain't gonna like this girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it is Kathleen Kelly. Joe elbows Kevin aside and looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to let her just wait  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Yes I am.  That's exactly what  I'm going to do.  Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she wrote the letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Kevin.  I'll see you  tomorrow. He walks away, leaving Kevin. Kevin stares after him.  Then he walks away in the other  direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen, sitting alone, at a table for two, is drinking tea.  She's starting to feel a little foolish.  She check her watch. A loud, boisterous group comes in and sits at the table n to hers.  They're laughing.  A man from the group grabs t empty chair at Kathleen's table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind? Kathleen jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.  I'm expecting someone.   Please. She takes the chair back.  Sits down again.  She watches group as they playfully fight over the menus. She checks her watch again.  Then she opens her copy of P and Prejudice and looks at it.  She can't focus. A man comes into the restaurant and she looks up hopefull at him.  But he's going to meet another group of people. As he passes her table, he knocks the book and the flower onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

She jumps up and rescues the book and flower as if they w precious china. In the window, now, behind her, Joe appears.  He watches, she rearranges the book and the flower. He disappears from sight. A beat... He walks in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen Kelly.  Hello.  What a  coincidence.  Mind if I sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do.  I'm expecting someone. Joe picks up her book, looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pride and Prejudice. Kathleen grabs it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind? She places it back on the table, puts the rose into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know you were a Jane Austen  fan.  Not that it's a surprise.  I  bet you read it every year.  I bet  you just love Mr. Darcy, and that  your sentimental heart beats wildly  at the thought that he and whatever  her name is are really, honestly and  truly going to end up together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you please leave? Joe sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get up as soon as your friend  comes.  Is he late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heroine of Pride and Prejudice  is Elizabeth Bennet and she's one of  the greatest, most complex characters  ever written, not that you would  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact I've read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, good for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd discover a lot of things  if you really knew me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I really knew you, I know what I  would find -- instead of a brain, a  cash register, instead of a heart, a  bottom line. Kathleen is shocked at herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just had a breakthrough, and I  have to thank you for it.  For the  first time in my life, when confronted  with a horrible, insensitive person  I actually knew what I wanted to say  and I said it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you have a gift for it.  It  was a splendid mixture of poetry and  meanness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanness?  Let me tell you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't misunderstand me, I'm just  paying you a compliment. He lifts the book off the table.  Kathleen grabs for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this? She manages to get the book, leaving Joe with the rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have we have?  A red, no, crimson  rose, tucked into the pages.   Something you read about in a book,  no doubt.  One of those books with a  lady in a nightgown on the cover  about to throw herself off a cliff. She holds her hand out for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to me. Joe puts it between his mouth and his nose like a mustach

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a joke to you, isn't it?   Everything's a joke to you. She grabs the rose.  Puts it back in the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please leave.  I beg you. He stands up, walks from the table, sits down at the very next table, with his back to her. The door to the restaurant opens.  Kathleen looks at it  hopefully.  A pleasant looking man, who's immediately joi by a pleasant looking woman. For a moment, Kathleen looks just a little droopy, as if wind has just gone out of her sails.  She takes out her  compact, looks into her mirror.  She slides it over to lo behind her, at him, just as he's looking sideways at her. He turns away suddenly. Then she blots her lipstick with her handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what the handkerchief reminds  me of?  The first day I met you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first day you lied to me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't lie to you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did too --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought all that Fox stuff was so  charming.  F-O-X.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never lied about it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Joe.  Just call me Joe."  As if you  were one of those stupid 22-year-old  girls with no last name.  "Hi, I'm  Kimberley."  "Hi, I'm Janice."  What's  wrong with them?  Don't they know  you're supposed to have last names?   It's like they're a whole generation  of cocktail waitresses. She stops herself -- it's a tangent she never meant to go off on.  But Joe has stood up and seated himself back at table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not a stupid 22-year-old girl --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I meant --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when I said the thing about the  Price Club and cans of olive oil,  that wasn't what I meant either --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you poor sad multimillionaire.   I feel so sorry for you. The door opens and a large and very attractive TRANSVESTI in a boa comes in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am going to take a wild guess that  this isn't him, either.  Who is he,  I wonder.  Not, I gather, the world's  greatest living expert on Julius and  Ethel Rosenberg, but someone else  entirely.  Will you be you be mean  to him too?  Will you start out sweet  as sugar candy and then suddenly,  miraculously, like a bolt from the  blue, find that sharp little tongue  of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I won't.  Because the man who's  coming here tonight is completely  unlike you.  The man who is coming  here is kind and funny -- he has the  most wonderful sense of humor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's not here, he has a reason,  because there is not a cruel or  careless bone in his body.  I can't  expect you to know anything about a  person like that.  You've nothing  but a suit. A beat.  Joe gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is my cue.  Good night. Joe leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen comes down the street.  She drops the rose in th trash can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen comes in, drops the book on the table, takes off her coat and goes immediately to the computer.  She click on American Online.  Waits impatiently to connect.  Looks with anticipation at the mail box.

dialogues.speaker: THE COMPUTER SCREEN
dialogues.text: Hold on Kathleen as a tear starts down her face. She takes her handkerchief out of her sleeve and wipes he face and blows her nose.  Then looks at her handkerchief tosses it over her shoulder. She goes over to the bed and turns it down and slips out her shoes. Then she lies down on the bed, fully clothed.  She reache up to turn out the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joe turns on his closet light and hangs up his jacket.
The computer is on the desk, and the light on it illumina the room. Patricia is in the next room, eating matzos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I said to her, "If you think I  will even talk to you about paying  that kind of advance for an author  whose last book is being used as  trivets all over the world, you are  completely crazy." On Joe's face, barely bearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kevin and Joe walk through the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But underneath that disagreeable  exterior she could turn out to be --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A real bitch.  Let's not talk about  it.  I'm going back to the office.   You must have work to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.  This place is humming  like a top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen comes around the corner.  Christina is waitin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stood you up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen puts her purse into the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think something happened, something  terrible and unexpected that made it  impossible for him --
George walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't able to make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stood you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What could have happened? George looks suddenly stricken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't he come?  Maybe he showed  up, took one look at me and left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe there was a subway accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train was trapped underground with  him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And no phone. George continues to look stricken.  He's starting to shak his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or an automobile accident.  Those  cab drivers are maniacs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hit something and you slam right  into that plastic partition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His elbows could be in splints -- so  he can't really dial --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or he could be in the hospital in  one of those semi-private room with  like --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (together)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- no phone. They look at George.  Still shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to George)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? George hands them a New York Post.  They look at the cove

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be. Dead silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was arrested two blocks from the  cheesecake place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a picture? There it is.  It's of a man with his jacket pulled over h head. They all look at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that explains it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there was a phone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- but he got only one call and he  had to use it to call his lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are so lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could be dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you crazy?  This man couldn't  possibly be the rooftop killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember when you thought Frank might  be the Unabomber?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long did you sit there all alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that long.  Joe Fox came in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Fox!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk about it. (closes her eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get to work. They look around.  There's no one in the store and nothin to do. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be something to do.   There's always something to do. They hear the jingle of the front door.  They look hopefu toward it.  It's only Birdie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stood her up. Hold on Kathleen as the computer sound begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been thinking about you.   Last night I went to meet you and  you weren't there.  I wish I knew  why.  I felt so foolish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she types.  And we cut from her face to the screen as hear a voice-over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as I waited, someone else showed  up, a man who has made my professional  life a misery, and an amazing thing  happened -- I was able, for the first  time in my life, to say the exact  thing I wanted to say it.  And of  course, afterwards, I felt terrible.   Just as you said I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The E-mail from Kathleen continues as Joe reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was cruel, and I'm never cruel.   And even though I can hardly believe  what I said mattered to this man --  to him, I'm just a bug to be crushed --  but what if it did?  No matter what  he's done to me, there's no excuse  for my behavior.  Anyway, you are my  dear friend, and I so wanted to talk  to you.  I hope you have a good reason  for not being there last night, but  if you don't, and if we never really  connect again, I just want to tell  you how much it has meant to me to  know you were there. Joe sits there a second.  A moment of intense ambivalence Then he hits the Menu key and signs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye. Joe stands and leaves the room. The computer sits there. Hold on the computer.  We hear him open the refrigerator  door. We hear him close the refrigerator door.  He passes the den without even looking into it.  A moment later he  comes back into the room, stares at the computer.  He sta for the bedroom, changes his mind.  Circles the computer. He's going to go cold turkey if it kills him.
Fuck it.  He sits down.  Sign on.  Starts to type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am in Vancouver. He stops... Hits the delete button and erases the message

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was stuck in a meeting, which I  couldn't get out of it, and there  was no phone. He backspaces to erase "there was no phone." Screen now reads: I was stuck in a meeting, which I could get out of it.  Joe sits there thinking for a moment.  Th he starts typing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The electricity went out in the  building and we were trapped on the  18th floor and the telephone system  blew too. He stops and looks at it.  Then he types:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazingly enough. He sits looking at it. Then he deletes the whole thing. Sits looking at the blank screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you. He clicks the Yes box. Then he starts to type again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear friend: I cannot tell you what  happened to me last night, but I beg  you from the bottom of my heart to  forgive me for not being there. He deletes "for not being there." Then types again, after "to forgive me".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- for what happened.  I feel terrible  that you found yourself in a situation  that caused you additional pain.   But I'm absolutely sure that whatever  you said last night was provoked,  even deserved.  And everyone says  things they regret when they're  worried or stressed.  You were  expecting to see someone you trusted  and met the enemy instead.  The fault  is mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen and Christina walk down the street together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someday I'll explain everything.   Meanwhile, I'm still here.  Talk to  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he say anything about meeting  again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.  It doesn't matter.   We'll just be like George Bernard  Shaw and Mrs. Patrick Campbell and  write letters our whole lives -- They go into an apartment building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large rent-controlled West Side apartment.  Birdie is  pouring tea.  There's a plate of cookies. Christina is looking at the picture of Birdie as a young  woman, dressed in a sort of Carmen Miranda getup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where was this taken, Birdie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you had the thunderbolt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  What did you decide, dearie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close.  We're going to close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although it feels like such a failure.   It feels like I'm quitting.  It feels  like... Mom... She closes her eyes. Birdie sits down on the loveseat next to Kathleen, puts h arms around her.  Hold on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeping the store open doesn't keep  your mother alive, although sometimes  I think we all think it does. Christina looks over at the picture of Birdie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was it, Birdie?  That you had  the thunderbolt over? Birdie shakes her head.  She's not going to tell them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so romantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it wasn't meant to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ran Spain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The country.  He ran it.  That was  his job.  And then he died.  Just as  well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Frank and Kathleen go up the escalator, on their way t movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She fell in love with Generalissimo  Franco?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say that.  We don't know that  for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else could it have been?  It was  probably around 1960 --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, it's not like he was something  normal, like a socialist or an  anarchist or something --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It happened in Spain.  People do  really stupid things in foreign  countries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.  They buy leather jackets,  they go see Flamenco, they ride in  gondolas, they eat in restaurants  where guitarists sing Malaguena sola  Rosa, but they don't fall in love  with fascist dictators. They enter one of the theatres.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they find seats and sit down.  A trailer is playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birdie is a very kind person, she's  practically my surrogate mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well she's out of her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could never ever be with anyone  who doesn't take politics as seriously  as I do. The person in front of them turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hot dog is singing.  You need quiet  while a hot dog is singing? The two of them sit there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have something to tell you.  I  didn't vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the last mayoral election, when  Rudy Giuliani was running against  Ruth Messinger, I went to get a  manicure and forgot to vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when do you get manicures?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I suppose you could never be  with a woman who gets manicures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.  It's okay.  I forgive  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhhhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forgive me. Hold on them a beat. Kathleen stands and walks out of the theatre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen on the down escalator.  Frank scrambling to catc up with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on? Kathleen's upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.  What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk uptown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, this has been a big week, you're  closing the store --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that, Frank, really it's  not.  It's just... Frank...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, that was terrible of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To jump all over you when I'm the  one who's really...  Oh, God, I don't  know how to say this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we see Kathleen and Frank being served drinks in a gla in extension of a restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen looks at Frank, waiting for him to begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a wonderful person, Kathleen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm honored that you want to be  with me because you would never be  with anyone who wasn't truly worthy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel exactly the same way about  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, don't say that, please,  that just makes it worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? (he shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't love me? Frank shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't love me? Kathleen shakes her head no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we're so right for each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That woman on television, right?   Sidney-Ann. Frank nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, nothing's happened or  anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she's a Republican.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help myself. Kathleen pats him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you?  Is there someone  else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, somewhere out there, I'm sure.   Somewhere --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she throws up her  hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In cyberspace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Frank, carrying a typewriter, walks out off Kathleen's building and puts it into the back of a taxicab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a sign goes up in the window: "Closing This Week: All  Stock 40% off."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The store is crowded.  People are buying stacks of books. We hear brief snatches of conversation: Birdie telling a  customer she's planning to travel, Christina saying she's finally going to have to finish her dissertation, George  saying he's been offered a job at Foxbooks but even thoug it's okay with Kathleen, he wouldn't work there if it wer the last place on the earth. There is a frantic, rummage sale atmosphere. Kathleen, busy at the cash register, looks up for a minut at her beautiful store being ravaged by vultures.  We hea the sound of the computer and hear her voice-over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My store is closing this week.  I  own a store.  Did I ever tell you  that?  Probably not.  It's a lovely  store -- As a woman dumps a huge stack of books on the checkout ta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a tragedy. (yelling across the  shop to her husband)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, grab a copy of The Trumpet of  the Swan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and in a week, it will be something  really depressing, like a Baby Gap.   I am being amazingly brave --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do with  yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I'm going to take  some time.  I have a little money  saved.  I'm almost looking forward  to it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so cheerful I would make  Pollyanna throw up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came here every Saturday when I  was a little girl.  I remember when  your mother gave me Anne of Green  Gables.  "Read it with a box of  Kleenex," that's what she told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's looking down on you right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have promised myself I'm not going  to cry. A FORTH SHOPPER approaches the counter with a stack of bo up to his chin, and manages to slide the stack on the cou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should bomb Foxbooks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not their fault.  The truth is,  the world is just... different. She starts ringing up the sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen walks home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon we'll just be a memory.  In  fact, someone, some foolish person  will probably think it's a tribute  to this city, the way it keeps  changing on you, the way you can

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: never count on it, or something.  I  know, because that's the sort of  thing I'm always saying.  But the  truth is, I'm heartbroken.  I feel  as if part of me has died,  and my  mother has died all over again, and  no one can ever make it right. She stops in front of the window, watching the customers  lined up to buy books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen enters and looks around. She goes up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen walks into it. It's huge, of course.  With its reading area, and stage, room for displays, and child-size furniture, and so many  books and so many customers. Kathleen sits down on a little child-size chair, complete wilted. KATHLEEN FROM ANOTHER P.O.V. And now we see Joe watching her, from a distance.  She do see him. A woman browsing, stops a sales person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have the "Shoe" books?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "Shoe" books?  Who's the author?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  My friend told me my  daughter has to read the "Shoe" books,  so here I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noel Streatfeild.  Noel Streatfeild  wrote Ballet Shoes and Skating Shoes  and Theater Shoes and Movie Shoes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she starts crying as  she tells her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd start with Skating Shoes, it's  my favorite, although Ballet Shoes  is completely wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Streatfeild.  How do you spell that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. As she walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They know nothing, they know  absolutely nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ON JOE
dialogues.text: as he watches her.  We hear the sound of the computer. She starts out of the store.  And hold on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A screen which says Reply and which now reads "I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Joe at his computer, staring at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asshole. He backspaces, deleting.  Starts typing again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  I don't know what to  say.  Truly I don't.  And anything I  do say will sound trite.  I hope you  feel better. He sits there, appalled at his own triteness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a taxi comes down the street and stops in front of Joe building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I was thinking was she'd probably  make a great children's book editor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you think that? They get out of the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knows everything.  She has  flawless taste.  She's famous for  it.  The salesmen swear by her.  If  she likes it, it sells.  Period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they enter the lobby and walk toward the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're going to offer her a job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?  What else has she got to  do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that she's destitute --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can't imagine her working  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has a horrible personality,  she's...  nice to everyone all the  time.  It's exhausting.  And her  staff turnover is ... non-existent.   They've been there forever.  Until...  recently, when they all found out  they were going to lose their jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks to you. The elevator door is closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold the elevator! They get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Charlie, Veronica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last time, we rode in an elevator,  we made the deal of the century.   What is going to happen this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Grant's going to get me a part  in one of her movies, that's what's  going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your dream, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to the  conversation with  Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love how you've totally forgotten  you had any role in her current  situation.  It's so obtuse.  It  reminds me of someone ... Who?  Who  does it remind me of? (thinks for a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me! The elevator suddenly stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is stuck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be.
He pushes the open button.  Nothing.  Turns the key, hits the open button, flicks the emergency switch.  The he sta hitting the buttons in every possible combination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bang the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. Joe bangs the door.  Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope this thing doesn't plummet to  the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can it do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Joe Fox.  Who is this?  Hi,  Juan.  We're stuck on the sixth floor.   There are four of us --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabs the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and if you don't get your ass up  here in two shakes and get us out -- He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Veronica)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hot. Joe hands her his handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone should jump in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We jump.  The elevator thinks that  no one is here and it opens. Everyone stares at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One -- two -- three -- They all jump into the air. They all land. Nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patricia is sitting on the elevator floor, polishing her  nails. We hear the fire department banging outside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I ever get out of here, I'm going  to start speaking to my mother.  She  slept with Oscar, and maybe it was  Oscar's fault, I don't know, and  then she sold the story to Inside  Edition.  That could have been Oscar's  idea, too.  Who knows?  But I divorced  him.  I wonder what she's doing right  this minute.  I think of her...  whenever I hear about a new pill.   Ecstasy, Zoloft, Fenphen, I just  think, I hope Mama knows about that. She takes out a tissue and dabs at her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you can make up on Rosie.   That would be so great for the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to figure it  out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I ever get out of here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I ever get out of here, I'm having  my eyes lasered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm marrying Oreet.  I love her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should marry her.  I don't know  what's been stopping me. He takes out his wallet and looks at a picture of Oreet,  shows it to Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I ever get out of here, I'm going  to -- He stops, he looks at Patricia who is fishing through her purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is my TicTacs? (looks at Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? The firemen crowbar open the elevator door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Brinkley walk out on the dock toward Joe's boat. Joe is carrying Brinkley's pillow, his laptop and a suitc He boards his boat and goes below.  A light goes on.  We  hear the sound of the computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came home tonight and got into the  elevator to go to my apartment.  An  hour later, I got out of the elevator  and Brinkley and I moved out.   Suddenly everything had become clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small sleeping area with a berth and a little table, wh Joe's laptop has been hooked up to the phone. Joe is on the narrow berth, as is Brinkley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a long story.  Full of the  personal details we avoid so  carefully... Joe puts Brinkley on the floor, on his pillow.  Brinkley  jumps back onto the berth with Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen is making tea.  She starts toward the bedroom. see her computer, now hooked up in the living room, where all of Frank's typewriters used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder whether change isn't a kind  of infection.  You start with one  thing -- something you never ever  thought would change and it does --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and the next thing you know even  your bed is in a different place. Kathleen enters the bedroom and we see the entire room ha been rearranged. She gets into bed and turns on the television set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bookshelves are empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six months ago, when you and I first  met, I knew everything about myself --  what I would be doing for the rest  of my life and even the person I  would be doing it with.  Now I know  nothing. On the door is a small sign.  "After 42 years, we are clo our doors.  We have loved being part of your lives." Kathleen turns out the light in the store and opens the d The little bell over the door jingles. Kathleen reaches up on her tiptoes for the bell and detac it. Then she comes out of the store, carrying the bell. Kathleen locks the door and reaches down to operate the g for the last time. The grate starts to lower. Kathleen looks at her store, one last time.  Then she wal off, carrying the bell.  We hear it jingle in the night.
And hold on The Shop Around the Corner, and it slowly tur into a computer-enhanced version of itself. And then, suddenly, it vanishes with a poof, leaving an e screen.

dialogues.speaker: A COMPUTER VERSION OF COLUMBUS AVENUE
dialogues.text: The trees sprout leaves and birdies start to tweet.  And scene turns into a real version of:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is now the head of the children department at the  store and he is sitting in the children's section on an i bitty chair.  His staff is sitting on little itty-bitty c too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, in the 19th century, Caldecott  revolutionized the publishing of  children's books by the introduction  of color illustrations --

dialogues.speaker: THE STAFF
dialogues.text: Several are dozing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe walks past the Eleanor Roosevelt statue.  He's with  Annabel and Matt:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about going to the Children's  Zoo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to go to the Children's  Zoo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  The Staten Island Ferry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go to the Storybook Lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go to the Storybook Lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we can't go to the Storybook  Lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabel is sitting in her chair, staring glumly at a bowl Japanese soup and noodles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll read you a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did she go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had to close her store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't have enough business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  Her store was very close to  our store, and you know our store  sells books at a slightly lower cost --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do we sell at a lower cost?  So  more people can buy books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why couldn't she sell that way too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she's small and we're big.   How about we go get some candy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now she's gone and it's all your  fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's business, Annabel.  It's not  personal.  How about we go get so  much candy you'll be bouncing off  the walls for days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's personal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personal means that she's gone  forever, and now we'll never get  another book from her as long as we  ever live. She burst into tears.  Matt bursts into tears too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember the man who worked with  her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a wail)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I hired him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You killed the Storybook Lady. Matt throws himself on the ground, crying. Annabel sobs hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is wearing the same pointed hat Kathleen wore as t Storybook Lady.  There's a sign that says: Storybook Pers Several children are listening.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: She's glowering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen is in bed with a huge box of Kleenex.  She has a terrible cold.  Her nose is red, her eyes are watery.  On the bedside table are a huge assortment of atomizers, pil etc.
We hear the sound of computer keys clicking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why haven't you written?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Joe on his computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your cold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ears are blocked, my nose is  clogged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's drinking cranberry juice.  Joni Mitchell on the ste The sound of computer keys clicking again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you feeling any better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm lying in bed listening to Joni  Mitchell and drinking cranberry juice  which I am sorry to say is the exact  same color as my nose.  I keep  thinking about my future.  What  future?  What am I going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joe is walking Brinkley back to the boat.  A limousine has pulled up near the pier and the driver is unloading b Joe stops to see the passenger: his father, Nelson Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next to Joe's boat is a larger yacht.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the main cabin Joe and Nelson are having drinks.  Nels lifts his glass in a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father and son, together at last.   That happened with Gillian? Nelson ignores the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've stayed here after, let's see,  your mother, Laurette that ballet  dancer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the nanny --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was she the nanny?  I forgot that.   How ironic.  Then there was the ice  skater --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- also the nanny --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.  How amazingly ironic.  Sybil  the astrologer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose moon turned out to be in  somebody else's house, as I recall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like Gillian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gillian ran off with someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nanny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nanny Maureen?  Gillian ran off with  Nanny Maureen?  That's incredibly  ironic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no other word for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did you break up with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patricia.  You met her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would I like her? (cracks himself up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just kidding.  Isn't this great?   Have some peanuts.  Of course I have  to live out of a suitcase for a least  three weeks, and then there's the  inevitable legal hassle, more of  your inheritance down the drain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't.  But then I get to meet  someone new.  That's the easy part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right, a snap to find the one  single person in the world who fills  your heart with joy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be ridiculous.  Have I ever  been with anyone who fits that  description?  Have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On to the next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it a beautiful night? Hold on Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, on his way to Kathleen's apartment building, carryin bunch of daisies, wrapped in cellophane. Joe goes up the stoop to her building and looks at buzzer Sees Kelly, 3A.  He presses.  Nothing.  Presses again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice clogged, through  intercom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen, in her pajamas, at the intercom, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I please come up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really not a good idea. Someone else walks up to the door, unlocks it and walks i Joe follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the intercom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a terrible cold, can you hear  it?  I'm sniffling and not really  awake --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen continues to talk through the Intercom to an  empty stoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and I'm sleeping practically twenty- four hours a day, and taking echinacea --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into intercom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
