dialogues.text: -- and vitamin C, so I would really  appreciate it if you would come some other time -- There's a knock on the door right next to her.  Kathleen  practically jumps out of her skin.  She looks through the peephole.  There he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a second.
She puts on a robe, runs frantically about picking up var scattered wadded-up Kleenexs, opens the front door.  Joe holding a bunch of flowers wrapped in paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you were sick and I was  worried and I wanted to -- (he hears voices)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is someone here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the Home Shopping Network.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bought any porcelain dolls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking about it. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You put me out of business --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now you turn up with flowers?   Did you come to gloat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To offer me a job --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I wouldn't think of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I have plans, I have lots of  offers.  I've been offered a job by --  well, actually by --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My former?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Former?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We broke up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too bad.  You seemed so perfect  for each other. (she claps her hand  over her mouth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean to say things like that.   No matter what you have done to me,  there is no excuse for my saying  anything like that.  But every time  I see you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things like that just seem to fly  out of your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I'm sorry.  I'm starting over. (sharply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming.  Goodbye. (she says it again, a  little more nicely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming. Goodbye. She starts to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bought you flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (trying as hard as  she can)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. She takes them. He takes them back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't I put them in water? He heads for the kitchen.  A beat, while she stares after him. Then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Kathleen gets to the kitchen, Joe is checking the ke for water.  Turns on the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sick.  Sit down, please. He pulls out a kitchen chair.  Kathleen sits.  She's a li woozy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vase?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upper left. He gets out a vase.  Fills it with water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George says hello.  He told me you  weren't feeling well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.  He's revolutionizing the  place.  No one is allowed to work in  his department who doesn't have a  Ph.D. in children's literature. He unwraps the paper around the flowers.  Daisies.  Puts  them in a vase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love daisies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me. He puts the vase on the kitchen table.  Kathleen plays wi the petals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're so friendly.  Don't you think  they are the friendliest flower?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you break up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, a couple of weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is breaking up.  You.  Me.   This other person I know broke up  with someone in an elevator.  I think  it was in an elevator.  Or just  outside it.  Or after it.  It got  stuck.  I think.  And suddenly  everything became clear.  When I saw  you, at the coffee place, I was  waiting for him and I was --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was not charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you looked charming. The teakettle whistles.  Joe turns off the burner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upper right. He gets out mugs and teabags and pours the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was upset.  And I was horrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey? Kathleen nods.  He puts in two spoonfuls, gives it to her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was horrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True.  But I have no excuse. She picks up the daisies and carries them into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe follows her.  They both sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whereas I am a horrible person and  have no choice but to be horrible,  is that what you're saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I am not saying that because I am  done saying horrible things, even to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did it again. She claps her hand over her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put you out of business.  You're  entitled to hate me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't hate you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you'll never forgive me.  Like  Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth Bennet in Pride and  Prejudice.  She was too proud --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you hated Pride and  Prejudice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- or was she too prejudiced and Mr.  Darcy too proud?  I can never  remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't personal --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- It was business.  What is that  supposed to mean?  I am so sick of  that.  All it means is it's not  personal to you, but it's personal  to me, it's personal to a lot of  people. (she shrugs helplessly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with personal anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, whatever else anything is,  it ought to begin by being personal. Kathleen stands up, picks up the daisies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My head's starting to get funny.  I  have to go back to bed. They walk to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen puts the daisies next to the bed and gets into i She fluffs up the pillows, pulls up the blankets, surroun herself with Kleenex and Evian and sneezes a gigantic sne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you stop by?  I forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to be your friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it wasn't possible.  What can  I say?  Sometimes a person just wants  the impossible.  Could I ask you  something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened with that guy at the  cafe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're crazy about him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why don't you run off with him?   What are you waiting for?
A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't actually know him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We only know each other -- oh God,  you're not going to believe this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me guess.  From the Internet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've Got Mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very powerful words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Joe sits on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy for him.  Although -- could  I make a little suggestion?  I think  you should meet him.  No.  I take it  back.  Why meet him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to get sharp  again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hardly think I need advice from  someone who -- He reaches out and gently claps his hand over her mouth. And holds it there.  It's unexpectedly tender and sexy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I concede I bring out the worst in  you, but let me help you not to say  something you'll just torture yourself  about for years to come. She starts to smile and he removes his hand.
They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you're better soon.  It would  be a shame to miss New York in the  spring. Joe stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for the daisies. He starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye. We hear the door close. Hold on Kathleen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christina is running.  She sees a good-looking MALE RUNNE coming toward her.  She has no hope that he will notice h and starts to look away as they get close to one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. He passes her.  Christina can't believe it. She does a little dance of joy. Camera pulls back as we see her by the reservoir on a  beautiful morning doing her little celebratory spin. Then she resumes her morning exercise, running on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patricia comes in.

The place is packed.  There are hundreds of young Jewish Yorkers singing folk songs and dancing the hora.  The Rab is dancing among them. Patricia sees the rabbi, leading the dance. The rabbi whirls madly toward her, like a human dreidel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shabbat shalom! He grabs Patricia's hand, and to her surprise, they go  whirling off together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen at the computer, typing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been thinking about this and  I think we should meet. She clicks the send button and then exits from America On Line. On her computer screen we now see the standard screen wit several icons: American On-Line, Word, Recycle Bin, etc. She clicks Word. She goes to File: New. There are several choices of format. She stares at the choices.  Then she clicks Book format. A blank page appears in the computer. She starts to type:  "Once upon a time there was a little girl named..." She pauses for a moment and looks around the room.  She s the flowers that Joe brought her. And then she types: "Daisy." As she goes on typing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Joe typing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should meet.  And we will meet.   But I'm in the middle of a project  that needs... (he pauses to think  of the right word)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... tweaking. A look of calculation on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see Kathleen through the window, drinking a cup of coffee. And now we see Joe walk into Starbucks.  He waves at her, pretending surprise at seeing her.  Has he been watching store and waiting for her to come in?  We'll never know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sitting next to her at the counter in the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tweaking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's probably married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a terrible thing to say.   It's not possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you asked him if he's married?   Have you said, "Are you married?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Joe looks at her, shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know this is probably a little  late to be asking, but are you  married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I married?  What kind of a question  is that?  How can you ask me that?   Don't you know me at all?  Oh wait,  I get it.  Your friends are telling  you the reason we haven't met is  that I'm married.  Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathleen and Joe having nachos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he didn't exactly answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did too.  He nailed me.  He knew  exactly what I was up to.  Which is  just like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he didn't exactly answer, did  he?  Did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's fat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't care that he might be one  of those guys who's so fat he has to  be removed from his house with a  crane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very unlikely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why else do you think he's putting  off meeting you?  Although... maybe  that's not it.  Maybe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What????

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could be waiting til he's paroled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you won't believe this, there  was a moment when George thought he  might be the rooftop killer, which  was completely ridiculous -- Her voice trails off, as she considers whether it could b true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his handle? She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, I'm not going to write him.   Is that what you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One five two.  One hundred fifty  two.  Very interesting.  He's 152  years old.  He has 152 hairs remaining  on his head.  He's had 152 moles  removed and now he has 152 pockmarks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk past tables of bread and flowers, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His combined college board scores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His IQ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The number of women he's slept with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The number of times he's seen The  Godfather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the first good thing I've  heard about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His address.  No, no, no.  He would  never do anything that prosaic. On Joe, looking a little wounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing I really care about  besides the married thing... and the  jail thing... is the boat thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could never be with anyone who has  a boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that clinches it.  We'll never be  together.  I'll take care of these. He picks up a mango, squeezes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could never be with anyone who  likes Joni Mitchell. (singing, imitating  Joni)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "It's cloud's illusions I recall, I  really don't know clouds at all."  What does that mean? Joe waits for Kathleen to say she likes Joni Mitchell. But Kathleen doesn't say anything. She starts intently picking over apples, trying to find s she wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your book coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk away from the market, going uptown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a children's book editor I  know, from the store, and she's  excited to read it.  When I finish  it.  Who would ever have thought I'd  write?  I mean, if I didn't have all  this free time, I would never have  discovered -- She stops, realizing what she's saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth is, he was the one who  made me start thinking about writing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister 152 Felony Indictments --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister 152... insights into my soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Well.  Can't compete with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  I keep bumping into you.   Hope your mango's ripe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it is.  Want to bump into me  Saturday?  Around lunchtime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joe types.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about meeting Saturday?  The  first day of spring.  4 P.M.  There's  a place in Riverside Park at 88th  Street where the path curves and  when you come around the curve, you'll  find me waiting.

dialogues.speaker: INT./EXT. SATURDAY
dialogues.text: Kathleen and Joe are putting mustard on their hot dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  In Riverside Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that amazing?  Maybe I've seen  him, and I don't even know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk uptown, eating their hot dogs and drinking p drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could be the Zipper Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy on Amsterdam who repairs  zippers.  You'll never have to buy  new luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop teasing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Timing is everything.  He waited  until you were primed.  Until you  knew there was no other man you could  ever love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost believe it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wonder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? They stop walking, they look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I hadn't been Foxbooks and you  hadn't been The Shop Around the Corner  and we'd just met --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have asked for your phone  number and I wouldn't have been able  to wait 24 hours before calling and  asking, "How about coffee, drinks,  dinner, a movie, for as long as we  both shall live?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost a swoon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then we would never have been at  war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only fight we'd ever have is  what video to rent on Saturday night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who fights about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people.  Not us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We would never. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.  I have to go. She doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something?  How come  you'll forgive him for standing you  up and you won't forgive me for a  little tiny thing like putting you  out of business? Kathleen looks at him.  Shakes her head. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh how I wish you would. It's all Kathleen can do not to forgive him. It's all Joe can do not to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really do have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to be late. She's in agony. He turns and walks away. After a moment, she does too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we see Kathleen come down the street and walk into her house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she comes out of the apartment house, having changed h clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she comes toward the entrance to the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kathleen comes down a path in the park, near 88th Stre She comes to a stop. Looks around. A young woman in running clothes passes by. A young father pushing a baby in one of those strollers  runners use to push babies in. Kathleen looks at her watch. Suddenly she hears a noise.  A dog barking. And Brinkley comes around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brinkley!  Brinkley!
And hold on Kathleen as she sees.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: And she starts to cry. And he comes to her.  And puts his arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't cry, Shopgirl, don't cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted it to be you.  I wanted it  to be you so badly. And as they kiss, we hold on them. And crane up and away as we see them, a couple kissing in the park on a beautiful spring day. A dog is leaping around them. And as we get further and further away from them, the scr turns into

dialogues.speaker: CYBERSPACE
dialogues.text: And the dog turns cartwheels and flipflops. And we tilt up to see the clouds and the sky and hear the sound of computer keys, clicking, clicking, clicking
